document.docAuthor: Rodrigues, Bruno V. B. & Rheims, Cristina A.
document.masterDocTitle: An overview of the African genera of Prodidominae spiders: descriptions and remarks (Araneae: Gnaphosidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: An overview of the African genera of Prodidominae spiders: descriptions and remarks (Araneae: Gnaphosidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Prodidomus scaber
Purcell, 1904: 172
, pl. 11, figs 41, 42 (Female holotype from Prince Albert , Western Cape [ 33°13’36.57”S , 22°2’8.57”E ], South Africa , deposited in SAMC 3016 , examined).

Austrodomus scaber Cooke, 1964: 264
, figs 32, 37, 60 (only female; male =
Purcelliana problematica Cooke, 1964
).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Males of
Austrodomus scaber
differ from those of
A. gamsberg
sp. nov.
by the palp with the distal half of the embolus slender and tapering (distal half of the embolus robust and ventrally bent in the middle in
A. gamsberg
sp. nov. )
( Figs 6A, C , 8A, B ). Females resemble those of
A. zuluensis
in having the posterior margin of the epigynal plate sinuous and without posterior projections ( Figs 7A , 8D ), but differ by the vulva with the laterally convoluted part of the copulatory ducts almost the same width as the proximal part (1/3 of the width in
A. zuluensis
), and by the inconspicuous spermathecae (well-defined in
A. zuluensis
) ( Fig. 8E ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2 .
Austrodomus scaber
, female: (A) habitus, dorsal view.
A. zuluensis
, female: (B) habitus, dorsal view; (C) chelicerae, frontal view; (D) sternum and endites; (E) spinnerets, lateral view; (F) spinnerets, ventral view.

FIGURE 3 .
Austrodomus scaber
, female: (A) carapace, dorsal view; (B) carapace, frontal view; (C) sternum; (D) endites, ventral view; (E) chelicera, promargin; (F) chelicera, retromargin.

FIGURE 4 .
Austrodomus scaber
, female: (A) tarsus IV, claw, retrolateral view; (B) tarsus II, claw, retrolateral view; (C) same, trichobothrium; (D) tarsus I, ventro-apical, arrow indicating modified setae; (E) female palp, retrolateral view; (F) same, tarsus, frontal view.

FIGURE 5 .
Austrodomus scaber
, spinnerets, male: (A) ALS; (B) PMS and PLS. Spinnerets, female: (C) ventral view; (D) ALS, major ampulate gland spigots; (E) PLS; (F) PMS. Ac—aciniform gland spigots; ALS—anterior lateral spinnerets; MiAm—cylindrical gland spigots; MaAm—major ampulate gland spigots; MiAm—minor ampulate gland spigots; Pi—piriform gland spigots; PLS—posterior lateral spinnerets; PMS—posterior median spinnerets.

FIGURE 6 .
Austrodomus scaber
, male: (A) palp, ventral view; (B) same, retrolateral view; (C) same, dorso-prolateral view; (D) same, detail bulb ventro-apical. Female: (E) epigyne, ventral view; (F) vulva, dorsal view. C—conductor; CD—copulatory duct; CO—copulatory opening; dRTA—dorsal retrolateral tibial apophysis; E—embolus; FD—fertilization duct; LETe—laminar extension of tegulum; vRTA—ventral retrolateral tibial apophysis.

FIGURE 7 .
Austrodomus zuluensis
, female: (A) epigyne, ventral view; (B) vulva, dorsal view, arrow to swollen pouch-like area; (C) vulva, schematic course of internal duct system.
A. oxoniensis
comb. nov .
Female: (D) epigyne, ventral view; (E) vulva, dorsal view, arrow to swollen pouch-like area; (F) vulva, schematic course of internal duct system. CD—copulatory duct; CO—copulatory opening; FD—fertilization duct; PS—primary spermathecae. Scale bars: 0.25 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female . (NCA 2013/5520). Total length: 2.81. Carapace 1.25 long, 0.82 wide; Abdomen 1.45 long, 1.15 wide; Sternum 0.86 long, 0.62 wide; Spinnerets ALS 0.25 long, 0.22 wide. Eye diameters: AME 0.09, ALE 0.08, PME 0.09, PLE 0.09; interdistances: AME–AME 0.04, PME–PME 0.07. Chelicerae 0.52 long. Leg measurements: I: 3.60 (1.0, 0.69, 0.73, 0.64, 0.55); II: 3.0 (0.88, 0.54, 0.60, 0.55, 0.44); III: 2.66 (0.73, 0.44, 0.56, 0.49, 0.45); IV: 4.16 (1.08, 0.58, 1.06, 0.83, 0.63). Leg formula 4123. Leg spination: III—femur d0-1-0; tibia v2-1r-1r, r0-1-0; metatarsus v0-0-2, r0-1-1. IV—femur d1-1-0; tibia v1r-2-2, r0-1-0; metatarsus v1r-1r-2. Epigyne: copulatory openings small, slightly larger than posterior pouch-like structures, separated from each other by half their width ( Fig. 8D ).
Distribution. South Africa and Namibia ( Fig. 10 ).
